p.content: This section covers copular, intransitive, transitive, ditransitive and passive sentences in their basic surface word order (i.e. not changed by focus, topic, interrogative, or negation constructions). As noted in section
, the typology of
is

case.caseText: SVO, so the basic word order is the subject, then any auxiliary elements, then the verb phrase which consists of the verb in initial position and any complements following it.
SOV, so the basic word order is the subject, then the verb phrase which consists of the verb in final position with any complements preceding it, then any auxiliary elements.
VSO, so the basic word order is the verb in initial position, then the subject, then any complements.
VOS, so the basic word order is the verb phrase which consists of the verb in initial position and any complements following it, then any auxiliary elements, then the subject.
OVS, so the basic word order is the verb phrase which consists of the verb in final position with any complements preceding it, then any auxiliary elements, then the subject.
OSV, so the basic word order is any verbal complements first, then the subject, then the verb in final position.

text.content: The word order changes with any auxiliaries present will be discussed in section

p.content: Before discussing each of the sentence types in turn, general issues of inflection and agreement features, pro-drop, and auxiliaries will be covered.
Verbs and auxiliaries usually carry inflection features, such as tense, aspect, and/or mood. In most cases, these features are added by affixes, but may also be part of irregular verb forms.
The following inflection features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in

Verbs and auxiliaries may also carry agreement features that force agreement with the subject, and sometimes also with the direct object. Most of these features are added by affixes or pronominal clitics which may attach to the verb. Animacy of a subject or object is most likely a property of the semantics of the individual verb itself.
The following agreement features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in

Some languages are called pro-drop languages because they allow a subject and/or object to be missing or unexpressed in their normal syntactic position. For example, in Spanish the normal way to say “I buy a book” is
p.langData: Compro un libro
p.content: rather than with the overt subject pronoun included:
p.langData: Yo compro un libro
p.content: . This is not allowed in English, except for imperatives. (The missing subject of infinitives in embedded complements will be covered in section

Some languages are not really pro-drop languages, but at least some of the pronouns are clitics which can attach to the verb. When this happens, there is no pronoun or nominal phrase in subject position, so the sentence appears the same as in a true pro-drop language.
In

case.caseText: pro-drop is not allowed. The subject must be overt except in imperatives.
pro-drop is not allowed. The subject must be overt even in imperatives.
pro-drop of the subject is allowed in any type of sentence.
the subject may look like it is missing due to pronominal clitics attaching to the verb, but it is not a true pro-drop language.
not
also

p.content: Examples showing a missing subject in imperatives include:
Examples of imperatives showing the overt subject include:
Examples with pro-drop include:
Examples that look like pro-drop due to clitic pronouns attached to the verb include:
There are several kinds of auxiliary elements, including positive and negative varieties, as well as nonfinite, motion and other types. Each type will be covered in turn.
Some languages have positive auxiliary elements that are separate words, and some can have more than one auxiliary element before the main verb. Examples for English transitive sentences include:
p.langData: The boy will hit the ball
The boy might have hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might have been hitting the ball

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: positive auxiliaries which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: optional
required
only one is possible
more than one may occur

text.content: After an auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before an auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: Examples of auxiliaries in
are:
Examples of sentences including these auxiliaries are:
In some languages verbal negation is an auxiliary element, while in others it is simply a verbal affix. English has both the negative auxiliary
p.langData: not
p.content: , which is a separate word that must always follow another auxiliary, and the contraction form
p.langData: -n’t
p.content: , which is written as a suffix on the auxiliary. Examples of English negative transitive sentences include:
p.langData: The boy did not hit the ball
The boy didn’t hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might not have hit the ball

case.caseText: has one or more
does not have any

p.content: negative auxiliaries which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: may
may not

text.content: be the only auxiliary in the phrase;

case.caseText: no other
the presence of another

p.content: In

case.caseText: there is also a negative affix which attaches to a positive auxiliary to make it negative,
there is not any negative affix which attaches to a positive auxiliary to make it negative,
and but there is a negative verbal affix.
but not nor any negative verbal affix.

p.content: The following chart summarizes the negative auxiliaries in

col.content: Negative Affix attached to an Auxiliary
Negative Affix attached to a Verb

p.content: See section
for examples of these negative elements used in sentences and further discussion of the negation constructions in
The nonfinite word
p.langData: to
p.content: used in English embedded clauses also acts as an auxiliary in that it fills the same position and can occur before other auxiliaries. For example,
p.langData: The boy would like to have hit the ball

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: nonfinite auxiliary-type markers which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: optional
required

text.content: After a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: The nonfinite auxiliary marker(s) in
is/are:
Examples of nonfinite clauses including these nonfinite auxiliaries are:
Some languages have other words that act like auxiliaries, such as motion auxiliaries or loan markers, which share the same subject and complements as the main verb.

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: auxiliaries of this type which are written as separate words.

text.content: After one of these auxiliaries, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before one of these auxiliaries, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: These other auxiliaries in
are:
Examples of sentences including these other auxiliaries are:
Copular constructions include those with a copular verb, if required, or with a perception verb, plus comparatives and existentials. Each will be discussed in turn.

True copular sentences can have an adjective, prepositional or postpositional phrase, or nominal phrase following the copular verb. Some languages do not require a copular verb or auxiliary to be present. English examples include
p.langData: The girl is pretty
Susan is sick
My sister is in the hospital
p.content: and
p.langData: He is the leader

p.content: In
copular sentences,

case.caseText: a copular verb is required.
a copular verb is optional, and no auxiliary is required either.
a copular verb is optional, but an auxiliary is required if the copular verb is not present.
there is no copular verb, but an auxiliary is required.
neither a copular verb nor an auxiliary is used.
not any copular affix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective either
a copular prefix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however
a copular suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however
either a copular prefix or suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however

text.content: , that occurs when there is no copular verb present.

p.content: Examples of copular sentences in
include:

In contrast to copular verbs, perception verbs usually only allow an adjective phrase following them, except in superlative constructions where a nominal phrase follows a perception verb, as shown in the next section. Some English examples with perception verbs include:
p.langData: The girl looks pretty
She seems nice
p.content: and
p.langData: The water appears murky

p.content: Examples of sentences with perception verbs in
include:
Both copular and perception verbs can also occur with an adjectival clause complement, where a sentence or complement clause follows the adjective. These constructions will be covered in section

Comparatives are a subtype of copular sentences. We will consider two types which rate two parts as equal, then comparatives where one part is better than the other, then superlatives. All of these types may normally use either a copular verb or a perception verb.
Comparison of equals can use a noun or an adjective for comparison. The noun equality construction uses a formula meaning ‘is the same
as’ between two nominal phrases. Some English examples are:
p.langData: The curtains look the same color as the walls
Your backpack is the same size as mine
p.content: and
p.langData: Sue has the same hairstyle as Mary

case.caseText: has a comparative degree word meaning ‘same’ which is used with the noun of comparison in sentences involving comparison of equals, as shown in the following chart.
attaches an affix or clitic meaning ‘same’ to the noun of comparison in sentences involving comparison of equals, as shown in the following chart.

does not have a comparative degree word meaning ‘same’. Only the presence of the two nominal phrases and the noun of comparison with the copular predicate occur in sentences involviong comparison of equals.

headerRow.headerCol: Equal Noun Comparative Degree Affix or Clitic

case.caseText: uses the following comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase in sentences involving comparison of equals:
does not have any comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase in sentences involving comparison of equals.

p.content: Examples of sentences expressing the noun equality construction in
include:
The second type of comparison of equals uses an adjective for comparison. This construction uses a formula meaning ‘is as
as’ between the two nominal phrases. Some English examples are:
p.langData: John is as friendly as Bill
Sue is as fast as Mary
p.content: and
p.langData: David appears as tall as Michael

case.caseText: has a comparative degree word meaning ‘as’ which is used with the adjective of comparison in sentences involving comparison of equals, as shown in the following chart.
does not have a comparative degree word meaning ‘as’. Its meaning is simply implied in the adjective of comparison sentences involving comparison of equals.
uses the following comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase in sentences involving comparison of equal qualitative adjectives:
does not have any comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase in sentences involving comparison of equal qualitative adjectives.

p.content: Examples of sentences expressing the adjective equality construction in
include:

Comparatives where one part is better than the other compare two nominal phrases using a comparative word meaning ‘than’, and include whatever copula the language uses, or a perception verb. Degree marking occurs with the predicate adjective or nominal phrase. In some languages, this degree marking may either be an independent degree word or an affix on the predicate adjective, as shown in the English examples:
p.langData: John is more handsome than Bill
Sue is a better runner than Mary
David appears taller than Michael
p.content: and
p.langData: Mary looks prettier than Julie

p.content: Note that there is an implied copula following the final nominal phrase in the English examples. A more complex type of comparative has an overt sentence in the place of the second noun phrase. These will be covered in section

case.caseText: has a comparative conjunction meaning ‘than’ which is used in comparatives where one part is better than the other, as shown in the following chart.

does not have a comparative conjunction meaning ‘than’. Only the presence of the two noun phrases and the degree word with the copular predicate signal a comparative where one part is better than the other.

p.content: In

case.caseText: there is not an affix to express the degree of comparison on predicate adjectives. A separate comparative degree word is used with both predicate adjectives and nominal phrases.
one or more affixes express the degree of comparison on predicate adjectives and one is always used with predicate adjectives in comparatives.
one or more affixes may express the degree of comparison on predicate adjectives. However, some predicate adjectives use the affixes and some use the separate degree words in comparatives.

p.content: The comparative degree affixes used on the predicate adjectives are:
The comparative degree words used with predicate adjectives and predicate nominals are:
The comparative degree words used with predicate nominals are:
Examples of sentences expressing the comparison where one part is better than the other in
include:

Superlatives are another subtype of copular sentences, directly related to comparatives. They compare a nominal phrase to a group, which may be expressed as a prepositional or postpositional phrase or simply implied. Like comparatives, superlatives include whatever copula the language uses, or a perception verb, along with special superlative degree marking on the predicate adjective or nominal phrase. In some languages, the superlative degree marking may either be an independent degree word or an affix on the predicate adjective. This is shown in the English examples:
p.langData: John is the most handsome of the boys
Sue is the best runner (in the class
p.content: and
p.langData: Mary looks prettiest

p.content: As with comparatives in

case.caseText: there is not an affix to express the superlative degree on predicate adjectives. A separate superlative degree word is used with both predicate adjectives and nominal phrases.
one or more affixes express the superlative degree on predicate adjectives and one is always used with predicate adjectives in superlatives.
one or more affixes may express the superlative degree on predicate adjectives. However, some predicate adjectives use the affixes and some use the separate superlative degree words in superlatives.

p.content: The superlative degree affixes used on the predicate adjectives are:
The superlative degree words used with predicate adjectives and predicate nominals are:
The superlative degree words used with predicate nominals are:
Examples of superlative sentences in
include:
Existential sentences are similar to copular sentences, except that they use a word or words meaning
or
along with a nominal phrase and usually a location. English examples include:
p.langData: There is a book on the table
There are two men outside
p.content: and
p.langData: There is no more food

p.content: Some languages instead have a separate existential verb, such as
p.langData: hay
p.content: in Spanish. Other languages have a whole set of existential verbs which express the position of the object being described.

case.caseText: has one or more verbs used especially in existential sentences, and there is also a separate existential word meaning ‘there’ or ‘there exists’.
has one or more verbs used especially in existential sentences, and these verbs fully express the existential alone, like ‘hay’ in Spanish.
does not have special verbs for existential sentences. The normal copula is used, along with a separate existential word meaning ‘there’ or ‘there exists’.
does not use any verb in existential sentences. Only the separate existential word meaning ‘there’ or ‘there exists’ is used for existential sentences.

p.content: The verbs used in existential sentences in
are:
The existential word(s) meaning
or
used in existential sentences in
are:
Examples of existential sentences in
include:
Simple intransitives do not have any complements after the verb, such as in
p.langData: The girl swims
p.content: . Motion verbs include a location in the form of either a

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional or postpositional
prepositional or postpositional

p.content: phrase or adverb. English examples of motion verbs include
p.langData: The girl ran around the track
My mother went to the store
p.content: and
p.langData: My teacher came here

does not have a case system.

case.caseText: in most constructions
both Agent and Experiencer subjects use the same nominative
Agent subjects are nominative case while Experiencer subjects use the accusative
Agent subjects are nominative case while Experiencer subjects use the dative
pronouns for intransitive verbs.
case markers and pronouns for intransitive verbs.
(There is no distinct datve case.)
Under certain grammatical conditions, the case system switches to ergative-absolutive, where the normal case of subjects of intransitive verbs is absolutive.

p.content: The examples above verify that

case.caseText: both Agent and Experiencer subjects use the same absolutive
both Agent and Experiencer subjects use the same absolutive
Agent subjects are absolutive case while Experiencer subjects use the dative
pronouns for intransitive verbs.
case markers and pronouns for intransitive verbs.
(There is no distinct datve case.)

Examples of English transitive single-clause sentences include
p.langData: The batter will hit the ball
My baby wants that toy
p.content: and
p.langData: The dog might have buried his bone

examples of transitive sentences with an Experiencer subject which have pronouns in the subject and object positions include:
There is no distinction between the nominal phrases nor the pronouns used for Agent subjects and Experiencer subjects in the examples above, since
does not have a case system.
The examples above verify that

case.caseText: in most constructions
both Agent and Experiencer subjects use the same nominative
Agent subjects are nominative case while Experiencer subjects use the accusative
Agent subjects are nominative case while Experiencer subjects use the dative
pronouns for transitive verbs.
case markers and pronouns for transitive verbs.
(There is no distinct datve case.)
Under certain grammatical conditions, the case system switches to ergative-absolutive, where the normal case of subjects of transitive verbs is ergative.

p.content: The examples above verify that

case.caseText: both Agent and Experiencer subjects use the same ergative
Agent subjects are ergative case while Experiencer subjects use the absolutive
Agent subjects are absolutive case while Experiencer subjects use the dative
pronouns for transitive verbs.
case markers and pronouns for transitive verbs.
(There is no distinct datve case.)

p.content: Ditransitives can have the second object expressed as a

case.caseText: prepositional
postpositional
prepositional or postpositional
prepositional or postpositional

p.content: phrase or as a nominal phrase. Some languages, like English, allow both types via Dative Movement, as in
p.langData: The girl gave the gift to her mother
p.content: and
p.langData: The girl gave her mother the gift

p.content: In
, the second object in a ditransitive

case.caseText: is always a prepositional postpositional prepositional or postpositional prepositional or postpositional phrase.
is always a nominal phrase. The
can be either a prepositional postpositional prepositional or postpositional prepositional or postpositional phrase or a nominal phrase. When both objects are nominal phrases, the
direct object
indirect object

p.content: Examples of ditransitive sentences in
include:

Most languages also have passive sentences, where the Theme or Patient fills the subject position. The Agent may be optionally expressed in some languages, but is not allowed at all in others. If expressed, it may take the form of a PP (as in English with the particular preposition
p.langData: by
p.content: ) or of a nominal phrase, depending on the language. In addition, a particular auxiliary may be required in passives (a form of
p.langData: be
p.content: in English). English examples with and without an agent phrase, including some showing interaction with multiple auxiliaries are:
p.langData: The glass was broken
The glass was broken by the child
The ball might have been hit
p.content: and
p.langData: The ball might have been hit by the boy

case.caseText: does not have any passives.
has passives
may not be expressed.
may be expressed
prepositional phrase.
postpositional phrase.
prepositional or postpositional phrase.
prepositional or postpositional phrase.
nominal phrase.
is not
is

p.content: The

case.caseText: preposition
postposition
preposition or postposition
preposition or postposition

p.content: used to mark the Agent phrase in
is:
The auxiliary used in passives in
is:
Examples of passive sentences in
include:

Instead of promoting the object to subject as a passive does, antipassive is a verb voice that deletes the object of transitive verbs. Antipassives are found most often in languages with an ergative-absolutive case system, where the deletion of the object changes the subject from ergative case to absolutive case. It is also found in some languages with a nominative-accusative case system where there is verbal agreement with both the subject and object. In these languages, the antipassive is usually formed by deleting the object agreement affix. Most languages with the antipassive voice are Australian Aboriginal or Native American languages.
Similarly to the subject or Agent in passives, some languages allow the object or Patient to be optionally expressed in a prepositional or postpositional phrase.
In

case.caseText: the subject of a transitive verb changes to absolutive case when the object is deleted in antipassives.
the object agreement affix on the verb is deleted to signal an antipassive.
there is a verbal affix for antipassive that signals the change in grammatical roles. This affix is:

p.content: Examples of antipassives in
, with some including the optional object or Patient if allowed, are:

Some languages, such as Tagalog and other Austronesian languages, have affixes on the verb which help define the roles and relationships of the nominal phrases in the sentence. This is a voice change like passive in that it gives emphasis to a particular nominal phrase. The verbal affix marks which nominal phrase is prominent, and may involve a change in word order and/or case marking. For example, in Tagalog the voice marker reflects the role of the nominative argument.
In

case.caseText: the voice changes are indicated by word order changes instead of case marking.
the voice affix reflects the role of the nominative argument.
the voice affix reflects the role of the absolutive argument.

p.content: The following chart shows the verbal affixes used to indicate the voice of the sentence:
Examples showing changes in this type of voice marking in
include:

Causatives add an additional argument to the sentence. Some languages have single-clause causative sentences, where the verb is marked with an affix that introduces the additional argument. That is the type of construction addressed in this section.
English and Spanish only have syntactic causatives which consist of two clauses, such as:
p.langData: My mother made me clean my room
p.content: and
p.langData: The other girl caused us to break up
p.content: . This second type of causative will be handled more fully in section
In

case.caseText: the only causative sentences consist of two clauses with a main verb meaning ‘make’ or ‘cause’. Some examples of syntactic causatives are:
there is a verbal affix for causative that introduces an additional argument, and that is the only type of causative in the language. The causative affixes are:
there is a verbal affix for causative that introduces an additional argument, and syntactic causatives with two clauses are also possible. The causative affixes are:

p.content: Some examples of causatives using the causative affixes

case.caseText: as well as some syntactic causatives

p.content: are:
